summary: This is a legal commentary article by Joel Cohen published in the New York Law Journal on April 8, 2019. It analyzes the concept of prosecutorial discretion, using the Jeffrey Epstein case as a primary example of its potential misuse. The article discusses the lenient prosecution of Epstein, the role of high-powered lawyers, and compares it to other high-profile cases and legal principles.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the article's analysis on prosecutorial discretion. Described as having a sordid history of criminal relations with and serial rape of underage girls, who received a light prosecution and plea deal.

persons.name: Joel Cohen
persons.context: Author of the article, a former prosecutor and senior counsel at Stroock & Stroock & Lavan, and adjunct professor at Fordham Law School. He is analyzing the legal ethics of prosecutorial discretion.

persons.name: Dale J. Degenshein
persons.context: Special counsel at Stroock who assisted in the preparation of the article.

persons.name: Bennett Gershman
persons.context: Author of 'Prosecutorial Misconduct', cited extensively throughout the article as an authority on prosecutorial discretion and decision-making.

persons.name: Robert H. Jackson
persons.context: Former Attorney General and Supreme Court Justice whose famous speech on the dangers of prosecutorial power is quoted and discussed in the article.

persons.name: Jeffrey Dahmer
persons.context: Cited as an example of a defendant whose reprehensible conduct leaves no room for prosecutorial discretion against prosecution.

persons.name: Ted Kaczynski
persons.context: Cited as an example of a defendant whose reprehensible conduct leaves no room for prosecutorial discretion against prosecution.

persons.name: El Chapo
persons.context: Cited as an example of a defendant whose reprehensible conduct leaves no room for prosecutorial discretion against prosecution.

persons.name: John Gotti
persons.context: Cited as an example of a defendant whose reprehensible conduct leaves no room for prosecutorial discretion against prosecution.

persons.name: Osama bin Laden
persons.context: Cited as an example of a defendant whose reprehensible conduct leaves no room for prosecutorial discretion against prosecution.

persons.name: Jussie Smollett
persons.context: Referenced at the end of the article as a potential example of poor exercise of prosecutorial discretion.

connections.description: The article states Epstein was 'armed with a high-powered defense lawyer' and that the U.S. attorney acceded to his lawyers' requests to keep a non-prosecution deal under wraps.
Degenshein, special counsel at Stroock, assisted Cohen in the preparation of this legal commentary article.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Prosecution and Plea Deal
events.description: Epstein faced state prosecution in West Palm Beach and a federal investigation in Miami. The federal case was folded into the local prosecution, resulting in a non-prosecution agreement federally and a guilty plea in state court. He served 13 months in a private jail wing with work release.

events.title: Federal Judge Revisits Epstein Deal
events.description: A federal district judge, revisiting the Epstein case in 2019, found that the U.S. attorney violated the federal Crime Victims Reporting Act by not notifying victims of the settlement.

events.title: Attica Prison Riot Aftermath
events.description: Following the Attica prison riot, inmates were indicted but guards and administrators were not. The Second Circuit ruled courts cannot interfere with a U.S. attorney's discretionary power not to prosecute.

keyFacts: The article frames the Jeffrey Epstein case as a prime example of the potential misuse of prosecutorial discretion, where a defendant with immense resources received exceptionally lenient treatment.
It reveals that a federal judge in 2019 found the U.S. attorney handling Epstein's case violated the Crime Victims Reporting Act by not notifying victims of the non-prosecution agreement.
The legal analysis cites the Epstein deal as being orchestrated to accede to his lawyers' requests for secrecy, contrasting it with the ideal of objective, justice-seeking prosecution.

The commentary argues that while prosecutorial discretion is necessary for individualized justice, the Epstein case represents a 'glitch' where the system failed, potentially due to the defendant's power and connections.

The article places the Epstein prosecution in the broader context of legal ethics, citing authorities like Bennett Gershman and Robert H. Jackson on the dangers and proper exercise of prosecutorial power.
